version_a.description: Fixed version with multi-sig requirement for admin function addSupportedToken

ground_truth.root_cause: The addSupportedToken() admin function had no access control - anyone could call it to add arbitrary tokens. While the withdrawERC20For function requires multi-sig, administrative functions lacked the same protection, creating an attack vector for adding malicious tokens.
ground_truth.attack_vector: An attacker could call addSupportedToken() without authorization to add a malicious token contract, potentially enabling token-related attacks on the bridge. Note: The original Ronin incident involved validator key compromise (operational issue), but this differential focuses on the code-level access control vulnerability in admin functions.
ground_truth.impact: Funds lost: $625,000,000 (original incident - validator key compromise)
ground_truth.historical_context: The real Ronin hack was primarily an operational security failure where attackers compromised 5 out of 9 validator keys through social engineering. This differential addresses a separate code-level vulnerability: lack of multi-sig on admin functions.

differential_details.changes_description_a: Added multi-sig signature verification to addSupportedToken function (lines 181-194). Now requires valid validator signatures to add new tokens, preventing unauthorized token additions.
differential_details.changes_description_b: addSupportedToken function has no access control (lines 181-183), allowing anyone to add arbitrary tokens to the supported list.
differential_details.why_this_matters: The minimal fix adds multi-sig protection to admin functions, ensuring that critical operations like adding supported tokens require consensus among validators, preventing single-point-of-failure attacks on administrative capabilities.
